awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Power and Performance Optimal Distributed Transactions
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is working to advance the state of the art in the design of storage systems for large-scale websites like Facebook, Uber, and Google that are an integral part of our lives.  The project aims to benefit society by making such websites faster, easier to program, and less expensive to build.  It will produce research papers that guide industrial efforts and future researchers.  It will also produce and release working prototypes of new storage designs that industrial practitioners and other researchers can build off of or compare against.  The project will advance discovery and broaden participation by involving undergraduates from the University of Southern California and institutions that serve under-represented groups in research experiences, training graduate students, developing curriculum that integrates teaching and research, and by conducting outreach to K-12 students at schools that serve under-represented groups.

The goal of this project is to understand the fundamental tradeoffs between power and performance. The scope of power properties includes consistency models and transactions.  The scope of performance properties includes latency, throughput, and their combination. To understand what is not possible we will formulate, conjecture, and attempt to prove impossibility results. To demonstrate what is possible we will design new systems that touch the boundary of our impossibility results. We will implement our designs and publish the implementations publicly. We will evaluate our implementation at large scale to validate they provide the claimed properties and to quantify their benefits and overheads.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Large-scale web applications are an integral part of modern life. Their rapid development and large scale are made possible by separating the development of application logic from the complications of concurrent access and machine failures, which are hidden to varying degrees by storage systems. The degree of hiding, and thus ease of development, are determined by the storage system's consistency model with stronger models providing easier development. Stronger consistency models, however, often come with performance tradeoffs that make the application slower (it has higher latency), more expensive, and less energy efficient (it has lower throughput and thus more machines are needed to support it). This project explored whether apparent tradeoffs are fundamental or whether we can eliminate them.

We discovered through impossibility results that several of these tradeoffs are fundamental. Meaning that if a storage system provides the strongest form of consistency it necessarily cannot provide the best performance. These impossibility results have several implications. First, they guide us to not waste time trying to develop such systems. Second, they each indicate a bifurcation into two distinct classes of system to be developed so as to best serve the differing needs of different application. Third, they provide a (likely) feasible goal in terms of what is possible.

Guided by our impossibility results we developed several new storage systems that demonstrate that strong, though not the strongest, consistency is possible with ideal performance. We also developed systems that provide the strongest consistency and frequently, but not always, provide ideal performance. Finally, we also developed new consistency models that we proved are just as easy to develop with as the strongest models, but that provide better performance.


Last Modified: 06/11/2024
Modified by: Wyatt Lloyd
